'''Knesses Chizkiyahu''' was one of the first [[Lithuania]]n [[yeshiva]]s founded after the establishment of the [[Israel|State of Israel]] and one of the first [[Torah]] institutions in the northern part of the country. Originally founded in [[Zikhron Ya'akov]] in 1949, it relocated to [[Kfar Hasidim]], adjacent to [[Rekhasim]], in 1955, where it operates today with nearly 200 students and a [[kolel]].

==Early history==
Knesses Chizkiyahu was founded by Rabbi [[Noah Shimonowitz]], one of the greatest students of Rabbi [[Boruch Ber Leibowitz]],<ref>{{citation |last=Meller |first=Rabbi Shimon Yosef |title=The Brisker Rav, Volume One: The Life and Times of Maran HaGaon HaRav Yitzchok Ze'ev HaLevi Soloveichik, ztl |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=OXDPoTN1OH4C&pg=PA451|page=451 (ftn 45) |accessdate=1 November 2009}}</ref> who decided to open a yeshiva after surviving the [[The Holocaust|Holocaust]]. He visited the [[Avrohom Yeshaya Karelitz|Chazon Ish]] for his blessing and advice, and was told to seek a suitable location in the north of Israel, which at the time did not host any Torah institutions. Together with his brother-in-law, Rabbi Dovid Mishkovsky, Rabbi Shimonowitz established the yeshiva in the central synagogue of Zikhron Ya'akov and named it after Mishkovsky's father, Rabbi Chizkiyahu Yosef Mishkovsky, former Rav of Krinik, Poland. The initial enrollment of three students expanded to thirty students by the end of the first year.<ref name="Meringer">{{cite web |url=http://www.tog.co.il/he/Services/Service.asmx/AddNewMailFromSiteToMailList/Article.aspx?id=120 |last=Meringer |first=Motty |title=Yeshivas Knesses Chizkiyahu |date=29 April 2009 |accessdate=1 November 2009 |publisher=Etrog News}}</ref> 

In 1952, Rabbi [[Elyah Lopian]], the contemporary leader of the [[Mussar movement]], joined the staff as [[Mashgiach Ruchani]], together with his son-in-law, Rabbi Kalman Pinsky. Lopian's influence on the yeshiva was so pronounced that it continues to this day. As an example of one tradition which he instituted, any yeshiva student who fills a cup to wash his hands must refill it for the next user in line.<ref name="Meringer" />

==Move to Kfar Hasidim==
The yeshiva experienced much difficulty in its early years, as students lacked sleeping facilities and organized meals due to the country's difficult economic situation. The location of the yeshiva in the central synagogue also caused friction between the students and local residents coming to pray. The yeshiva administration decided to find a new building, and then to leave Zikhron Ya'akov altogether.

When the news spread that the yeshiva was seeking a new home, many [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox Jewish]] communities extended a hand of welcome, but none were located in the north where the Chazon Ish had desired a yeshiva to be founded. Finally, a group of activists from the northern village of Kfar Hasidim petitioned the yeshiva and were accepted.

With the blessing of the Chazon Ish, the yeshiva purchased a {{convert|10|dunam}} lot on the outskirts of the village and five buildings containing a [[beth midrash]], dining hall, dormitories and offices. The yeshiva moved into its new home at the end of April 1955.<ref name="Meringer" />

Five days after the move, the Rosh Yeshiva, Rabbi Shimonowitz, died of a [[stroke]]. Rabbi Lopian took charge and appointed Shimonowitz's brother-in-law, Rabbi [[Raphael Eliyahu Eliezer Mishkovsky]], who was also the Rav of Kfar Hasidim, as the new rosh yeshiva.<ref name=marks>Marks, Yehudah. "The Torah Empire of the North", ''[[Hamodia]]'' Israel News, March 19, 2015, pp. 21-23.</ref>

Mishkovsky worked together with Lopian to shape and guide the yeshiva and its students. In May 1964, they laid the cornerstone for a new building to house the many students who had outgrown the original site. This building is still in use today.

==Faculty==
Mishkovsky led the yeshiva until his death in 1981. He was succeeded as rosh yeshiva by his son-in-law, Rabbi Dovid Yitzchak Mann (1945–2012), who was succeeded upon his death by his eldest son, Rabbi Yehoshua Mann.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bhol.co.il/article.aspx/article_en.aspx?id=41541|title=Rosh Yeshivas Knesses Chizkiyahu, Hagrd"y Mann zt"l|work=Behadrei Hareidim|accessdate=21 August 2013|date=7 June 2013|last=Weissberg|first=Moshe}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://matzav.com/rav-dovid-yitzchok-man-ztl|title=Rav Dovid Yitzchok Man zt"l|last=Alpert|first=Yair|work=matzav.com|date=4 June 2013 |accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> The ''[[mashgiach ruchani]]'', Rabbi Elyah Lopian, died in 1970; he was succeeded by his protégé, Rabbi Dov Yaffe.

==Rosh yeshivas==
*Rabbi Noah Shimonowitz (1949–1955)
*Rabbi Raphael Eliyahu Eliezer Mishkovsky (1955–1981)
*Rabbi Dovid Yitzchak Mann (1981–2012)
*Rabbi Yehoshua Mann (2012-  )

==Notable alumni==

title: Membley Estate Ruiru
Fuzzy classification
content:
''Fuzzy classification'' is the process of grouping elements into a [[fuzzy set]]<ref>Zadeh, L. A. (1965). Fuzzy sets. Information and Control (8), pp. 338–353.</ref> whose [[membership function]] is defined by the truth value of a fuzzy propositional function.<ref>Zimmermann, H.-J. (2000). ''Practical Applications of Fuzzy Technologies''. Springer.</ref><ref>Meier, A., Schindler, G., & Werro, N. (2008). Fuzzy classification on relational databases. In M. Galindo (Hrsg.), Handbook of research on fuzzy information processing in databases (Bd. II, S. 586-614). Information Science Reference.</ref><ref>Del Amo, A., Montero, J., & Cutello, V. (1999). On the principles of fuzzy classification. Proc. 18th North American Fuzzy Information Processing Society Annual Conf, (S. 675 – 679).</ref>

A fuzzy class ~C = { i | ~Π(i) } is defined as a fuzzy set ~C of individuals i satisfying a fuzzy classification predicate ~Π which is a fuzzy propositional function. The domain of the fuzzy class operator ~{ .| .}  is the set of variables V and the set of fuzzy propositional functions ~PF, and the range is the fuzzy [[powerset]] (the set of fuzzy subsets) of this universe, ~P(U):

~{ .| .}∶V × ~PF ⟶ ~P(U)

A fuzzy propositional function is, analogous to,<ref name="Russel 1919">Russel, B. (1919). ''Introduction to Mathematical Philosophy''. London: George Allen & Unwin, Ltd., S. 155</ref> an expression containing one or more variables, such that, when values are assigned to these variables, the expression becomes a fuzzy proposition in the sense of.<ref name="Zadeh 1975">Zadeh, L. A. (1975). Calculus of fuzzy restrictions. In L. A. Zadeh, K.-S. Fu, K. Tanaka, & M. Shimura (Hrsg.), Fuzzy sets and Their Applications to Cognitive and Decision Processes. New York: Academic Press.</ref>

Accordingly, fuzzy classification is the process of grouping individuals having the same characteristics into a ''fuzzy set''. A fuzzy classification corresponds to a membership function μ that indicates whether an individual is a member of a class, given its fuzzy classification predicate ~Π.

μ∶~PF × U ⟶ ~T

Here, ~T is the set of fuzzy truth values (the interval between zero and one). The fuzzy classification predicate ~Π corresponds to a fuzzy restriction "i is R" <ref name="Zadeh 1975" /> of U, where R is a fuzzy set defined by a truth function. The degree of membership of an individual i in the fuzzy class ~C is defined by the truth value of the corresponding fuzzy predicate.

μ~C(i):= τ(~Π(i))

==Classification==
Intuitively, a class is a set that is defined by a certain property, and all objects having that property are elements of that class. The process of classification evaluates for a given set of objects whether they fulfill the classification property, and consequentially are a member of the corresponding class. However, this intuitive concept has some logical subtleties that need clarification.

A [[class logic]]<ref>Glubrecht, J.-M., Oberschelp, A., & Todt, G. (1983). Klassenlogik. Mannheim/Wien/Zürich: Wissenschaftsverlag.</ref> is a logical system which supports set construction using logical predicates with the class operator { .| .}. A ''class''

C = { i | Π(i) }

is defined as a set C of individuals i satisfying a classification predicate Π which is a propositional function. The domain of the class operator { .| .}  is the set of variables V and the set of propositional functions PF, and the range is the powerset of this universe P(U) that is, the set of possible subsets:

{ .| .} ∶V×PF⟶P(U)

Here is an explanation of the logical elements that constitute this definition:
* An individual is a real object of reference.
* A universe of discourse is the set of all possible individuals considered.
* A variable V:⟶R is a function which maps into a predefined range R without any given function arguments: a zero-place function.
* A propositional function is “an expression containing one or more undetermined constituents, such that, when values are assigned to these constituents, the expression becomes a proposition”.<ref name="Russel 1919" />

In contrast, ''classification'' is the process of grouping individuals having the same characteristics into a set. A classification corresponds to a membership function μ that indicates whether an individual is a member of a class, given its classification predicate Π.

μ∶PF × U ⟶ T

The membership function maps from the set of propositional functions PF and the universe of discourse U into the set of truth values T. The membership μ of individual i in Class C is defined by the truth value τ of the classification predicate Π.

μC(i):=τ(Π(i))

In classical logic the truth values are certain. Therefore a classification is crisp, since the truth values are either exactly true or exactly false.

==See also==
* [[Fuzzy logic]]

==References==
<references/>

{{DEFAULTSORT:Fuzzy Classification}}
[[Category:Fuzzy logic]]

title: Talk:Bernard II, Duke of Saxony
1980s in Angola
content:
{{20th century in Angola}}
In the '''1980s in Angola''', fighting spread outward from the southeast, where most of the fighting had taken place in the 1970s, as the African National Congress (ANC) and [[SWAPO]] increased their activity. The South African government responded by sending troops back into Angola, intervening in the war from 1981 to 1987,<ref name=a>{{cite book|last=Stearns|first=Peter N.|author2=Langer, William Leonard|year=2001|title=The Encyclopedia of World History: Ancient, Medieval, and Modern, Chronologically Arranged|page=1065}}</ref> prompting the [[Soviet Union]] to deliver massive amounts of military aid from 1981 to 1986. The USSR gave the Angolan government over US$2 billion in aid in 1984.<ref name=b>{{cite book|last=Zemtsov|first=Ilya|author2=John Farrar|year=1989|title=Gorbachev: The Man and the System|page=309}}</ref> In 1981, newly elected [[United States President]] [[Ronald Reagan]]'s U.S. assistant secretary of state for African affairs, [[Chester Crocker]], developed a [[Linkage (policy)|linkage policy]], tying [[Namibia]]n independence to Cuban withdrawal and peace in Angola.<ref name=c>{{cite book|last=Tvedten|first=Inge|year=1997|title=Angola: Struggle for Peace and Reconstruction|pages=38–39}}</ref><ref name=d>{{cite news|author=John Hashimoto|year=1999|url=http://edition.cnn.com/SPECIALS/cold.war/guides/debate/chats/crocker/|title=Cold War Chat: Chester Crocker, Former U.S. Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs|publisher=CNN|accessdate=2007-09-20|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20040831075950/http://edition.cnn.com/SPECIALS/cold.war/guides/debate/chats/crocker/ |archivedate = August 31, 2004|deadurl=yes}}</ref>

==South African attacks==
The South African military attacked insurgents in Cunene Province on May 12, 1980. The Angolan Ministry of Defense accused the South African government of wounding and killing civilians. Nine days later, the SADF attacked again, this time in Cuando-Cubango, and the MPLA threatened to respond militarily. The SADF launched a full-scale invasion of Angola through Cunene and Cuando-Cubango on June 7, destroying SWAPO's operational command headquarters on June 13, in what Prime Minister [[Pieter Willem Botha|Botha]] described as a "shock attack". The Angolan government arrested 120 Angolans who were planning to set off explosives in Luanda, on June 24, foiling a plot purportedly orchestrated by the South African government. Three days later, the [[United Nations Security Council]] convened at the behest of Angola's ambassador to the UN, E. de Figuerido, and condemned South Africa's incursions into Angola. President Mobutu of Zaire also sided with the MPLA. The Angolan government recorded 529 instances in which South African forces violated Angola's territorial sovereignty between January and June 1980.<ref name=e>{{cite book|last=Kalley|first=Jacqueline Audrey|year=1999|title=Southern African Political History: a chronological of key political events from independence to Mid-1997|pages=13–14}}</ref>

Cuba increased its 35,000-strong troop force in Angola from 35,000 in 1982 to 40,000 in 1985. South African forces tried to capture [[Lubango]], capital of [[Huíla province]], in [[Operation Askari]] in December 1983.<ref name=c/>

==Democratic International==
{{Main|Democratic International}}
[[File:Jonas Savimbi.jpg||thumb|right|200px|U.S.-supported [[UNITA]] leader [[Jonas Savimbi]].]]
On June 2, 1985, American conservative activists held the [[Democratic International]], a symbolic meeting of anti-Communist militants, at [[UNITA]]'s headquarters in [[Jamba, Angola]].<ref name=demint>{{cite book|last=Franklin|first=Jane|year=1997|title=Cuba and the United States: A Chronological History|page=212}}</ref> Primarily funded by [[Rite Aid]] founder [[Lewis Lehrman]] and organized by anti-Communist activists [[Jack Abramoff]] and Jack Wheeler, participants included Savimbi, [[Adolfo Calero]], leader of the [[Nicaragua]]n [[Contras]], [[Pa Kao Her]], [[Hmong people|Hmong]] [[Laos|Laotian]] rebel leader, U.S. [[Lieutenant Colonel]] [[Oliver North]], [[South Africa]]n security forces, [[Abdurrahim Wardak]], [[Afghanistan|Afghan]] [[Mujahideen]] leader, Jack Wheeler, American conservative policy advocate, and many others.<ref name=crusade>{{cite book|last=Easton|first=Nina J.|year=2000|title=Gang of Five: Leaders at the Center of the Conservative Crusade|pages=165–167}}</ref> While the [[Reagan administration]], though unwilling to publicly support the meeting, privately expressed approval. The governments of [[Israel]] and [[South Africa]] supported the idea, but both respective countries were deemed inadvisable for hosting the conference.<ref name=crusade/>

The participants released a communiqué stating,

:"We, free peoples fighting for our national independence and human rights, assembled at Jamba, declare our solidarity with all freedom movements in the world and state our commitment to cooperate to liberate our nations from the Soviet Imperialists."

==Clark Amendment==
{{Main|Clark Amendment}}
The [[United States House of Representatives]] voted 236 to 185 to repeal the Clark Amendment on July 11, 1985.<ref name=clarkrepeal>{{cite news|author=|year=|url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50816F93C5C0C728DDDAE0894DD484D81&n=Top%2fNews%2fWorld%2fCountries%20and%20Territories%2fAngola|title=House acts to allow Angola rebel aid|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=2007-09-20 | date=July 11, 1985 | first=Jonathan | last=Fuerbringer}}</ref> The Angolan government began attacking UNITA later that month from Luena towards Cazombo along the Benguela Railway, taking Cazombo on September 18. The government tried unsuccessfully to take UNITA's supply depot in [[Mavinga, Cuando Cubango|Mavinga]] from [[Menongue]]. While the attack failed, very different interpretations of the attack emerged. UNITA claimed Portuguese-speaking Soviet officers led government troops while the government said UNITA relied on South African paratroopers to defeat the government. The South African government admitted to fighting in the area, but said its troops fought [[SWAPO]] militants.<ref name=eightyfive>{{cite book|last=Zolberg|first=Aristide R.|author2=Astri Suhrke|author3=Sergio Aguayo|year=1989|title=Escape from Violence: Conflict and the Refugee Crisis in the Developing World|page=312}}</ref>

==A war intensifies==
{{main|Angolan Civil War}}
[[File:SWAPO and SA operations 1978-1980, Angola civil war.png|thumb|250px|right|SWAPO's and South Africa's operations (1978–1980)]]
By 1986, Angola began to assume a more central role in the [[Cold War]], with both the Soviet Union, Cuba and other East bloc nations enhancing support for the MPLA government, and American conservatives beginning to elevate their support for Savimbi's UNITA.  Savimbi developed close relations with influential American conservatives, who saw Savimbi as a key ally in the U.S. effort to oppose and rollback Soviet-backed, non-democratic governments around the world. The conflict quickly escalated, with both [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]] and [[Moscow]] seeing it as a critical strategic conflict in the Cold War.

The Soviet Union gave an additional $1 billion in aid to the Angolan government and Cuba sent an additional 2,000 troops to the 35,000 strong force in Angola to protect [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]] oil platforms in 1986.<ref name=eightyfive/> Savimbi had called Chevron's presence in Angola, already protected by Cuban troops, a "target" for UNITA in an interview with ''[[Foreign Policy magazine]]'' on January 31.<ref name=chevtarget>Franklin (1997). Page 219.</ref>

In Washington, Savimbi forged close relationships with influential conservatives, including [[Michael Johns (policy analyst)|Michael Johns]] (the [[Heritage Foundation]]'s foreign policy analyst and a key Savimbi advocate), [[Grover Norquist]] (President of [[Americans for Tax Reform]] and a Savimbi economic advisor), and others, who played critical roles in elevating escalated U.S. covert aide to Savimbi's UNITA and visited with Savimbi in his [[Jamba, Angola]] headquarters to provide the Angolan rebel leader with military, political and other guidance in his war against the Angolan government. With enhanced U.S. support, the war quickly escalated, both in terms of the intensity of the conflict and also in its perception as a key conflict in the overall Cold War.<ref>{{cite news|author=|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE5D8133DF932A35751C0A961948260|title=C.I.A. Said to Send Weapons Via Zaire to Angola Rebels|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=2007-12-27 | first=James | last=Brooke | date=February 1, 1987}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A0DEEDE1338F935A35751C0A960948260|title=A Mending of Fences|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=2007-12-27 | first1=Irvin | last1=Molotsky | first2=Warren | last2=Weaver Jr. | date=February 6, 1986}}</ref>

''[[The New York Times]]'' reported on February 1, 1987 that U.S. weapons shipments to UNITA were escalating considerably.  "According to the sources," ''The New York Times'' reported, "the light blue cargo planes of Santa Lucia Airways made arms deliveries on three occasions: between March 20 and April 20, for two weeks between May 15 and 30, and during one night in mid-October. Most of the landings were at night, but in May 'it was day and night -quite some activity,' one source said."<ref>[http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE5D8133DF932A35751C0A961948260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=1 "CIA Said to Send Weapons Via Zaire to Angola Rebels," ''The New York Times'', February 1, 1987.]</ref>

In addition to escalating its military support for UNITA, the Reagan administration and its conservative allies also worked to expand recognition of Savimbi as a key U.S. ally in an important Cold War struggle. In January 1986, Reagan invited Savimbi to meet with him at the [[White House]]. Following the meeting, Reagan spoke of UNITA winning a victory that "electrifies the world" at the [[White House]] in January 1986. Two months later, Reagan announced the delivery of [[FIM-92 Stinger|Stinger surface-to-air missiles]] as part of the $25 million in aid UNITA received from the U.S. government.<ref name=c/><ref name=electrifies>{{cite news|author=Chris Simpson|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/264094.stm|title=Obituary: Jonas Savimbi, Unita's local boy|accessdate=2007-09-20 | date=2002-02-25|work=BBC News}}</ref> [[Jeremias Chitunda]], UNITA's representative to the U.S., became the Vice President of UNITA in August 1986 at the sixth party congress.<ref name=chitpromo>{{cite book|last=Martin|first=James W.|year=2004|title=Historical Dictionary of Angola|page=33}}</ref> [[Fidel Castro]] made Crocker's proposal, the withdrawal of foreign troops from Angola and [[Namibia]], a prerequisite to Cuban withdrawal from Angola on September 10.

UNITA forces attacked Camabatela in [[Cuanza Norte]] province on February 8, 1986. ANGOP alleged UNITA massacred civilians in Damba in [[Uíge Province]] later that month, on February 26. The South African government agreed to Crocker's terms in principle on March 8. Savimbi proposed a truce regarding the [[Benguela railway]] on March 26, saying MPLA trains could pass through as long as an international inspection group monitored trains to prevent their use for counter-insurgency activity. The government did not respond. In April 1987 [[Fidel Castro]] sent Cuba's Fiftieth Brigade to southern Angola, increasing the number of Cuban troops by twelve to fifteen thousand troops.<ref name=fidthou>{{cite book|last=Kahn|first=Owen Ellison|year=1991|title=Disengagement from Southwest Africa: The Prospects for Peace in Angola and Namibia|page=213}}</ref> The Angolan and American governments began negotiating in June 1987.<ref name=eighties>Kalley (1999). Page 36.</ref><ref name=timeline>{{cite book|last=Alao|first=Abiodun|year=1994|title=Brothers at War: Dissidence and Rebellion in Southern Africa|page=XIX–XXI}}</ref>

===Cuito Cuanavale and New York City===
{{Main|Battle of Cuito Cuanavale|Tripartite Accord (Angola)}}
[[File:Angola Provinces Cuando Cubango 250px.png|right|thumb|Cuando Cubango province]]
UNITA and South African forces attacked the MPLA's base at [[Cuito Cuanavale]] in [[Cuando Cubango]] province from January 13 to March 23, [1988], in the second largest battle in the [[history of Africa]],<ref name=sechist>George (2005). Page 1.</ref> after the [[Second Battle of El Alamein|Battle of El Alamein]],<ref name=alamein>{{cite book|last=Mendelsohn|first=John|author2=Selma El Obeid|year=2004|title=Okavango River: The Flow of a Lifeline|page=56}}</ref> the largest in sub-Saharan Africa since [[World War II]].<ref name=sinceworldwar>Alao (1994). Pages 33–34.</ref> Cuito Cuanavale's importance came not from its size or its wealth but its location. The ensuing Battle of Cuito Cuanavale has since been disputed with both sides claiming victory.<ref name=c/><ref name=borderwar>{{cite book|last=Steenkamp|first=W|year=1989|title=South Africa's border war, 1966-1989|publisher=Gibraltar: Ashanti Pub.|isbn=978-0-620-13967-0}}</ref><ref name=covert>{{cite book|last=Stiff|first=P.|year=2000|title=The Covert War: Koevoet Operations in Namibia 1979-1989|publisher=Galago Publishihg Pty Ltd|isbn=978-1-919854-03-8}}</ref><ref name=cuitodate>{{cite book|last=Kahn|first=Owen Ellison|year=1991|title=Disengagement from Southwest Africa: The Prospects for Peace in Angola and Namibia|publisher=University of Miami Institute for Soviet and East|page=79}}</ref>

The Cuban government joined negotiations on January 28, 1988, and all three parties held a round of negotiations on March 9. The South African government joined negotiations on May 3 and the parties met in June and August in [[New York City]] and [[Geneva]]. All parties agreed to a ceasefire on August 8. Representatives from the governments of Angola, Cuba, and South Africa signed the [[Tripartite Accord (Angola)|Tripartite Accord]], granting independence to [[Namibia]] and ending the direct involvement of foreign troops in the civil war, in [[New York City]], [[United States]] on December 22, 1988.<ref name=timeline/><ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite book|last=Tvedten|first=Inge|year=1997|title=Angola: Struggle for Peace and Reconstruction|pages=38–40}}</ref> The [[United Nations Security Council]] passed Resolution 626 later that day, creating the [[United Nations Angola Verification Mission]], a UN peacekeeping force. UNAVEM troops began arriving in Angola in January 1989.<ref name=foreignwithdraw>{{cite book|last=Wellens|first=Karel C.|year=1990|title=Resolutions and Statements of the United Nations Security Council (1946–1989): A Thematic Guide|pages=235–236}}</ref><ref name=highnoon>{{cite book|last=Crocker|first=Chester A|authorlink=Chester Crocker|year=1992|title=High Noon in Southern Africa: Making Peace in a Rough Neighborhood.|publisher=W.W. Norton|isbn=978-0-393-03432-5}}</ref>

==Ceasefire==
{{Main|Gbadolite}}
As the Angolan Civil War began to take on a diplomatic component, in addition to a military one, two key Savimbi allies, [[The Conservative Caucus]]' [[Howard Phillips (politician)|Howard Phillips]] and the Heritage Foundation's Michael Johns visited Savimbi in Angola, where they sought to persuade Savimbi to come to the United States in the spring of 1989 to help the Conservative Caucus, the Heritage Foundation and other conservatives in making the case for continued U.S. aid to UNITA.<ref name=tcc>{{cite book|last=[[Russ Bellant|Bellant]]|first=Russ|year=1991|title=The Coors Connection: How Coors Family Philanthropy Undermines Democratic Pluralism|pages=53–54}}</ref>

President Mobutu invited eighteen African leaders, Savimbi, and dos Santos to his palace in [[Gbadolite]] in June 1989 for negotiations. Savimbi and dos Santos met for the first time and agreed to the Gbadolite Declaration, a ceasefire, on June 22, paving the way for a future peace agreement.<ref name=mobmeeting>{{cite book|last=Walker|first=John Frederick|year=2004|title=A Certain Curve of Horn: The Hundred-Year Quest for the Giant Sable Antelope of Angola|page=190}}</ref><ref name=gbad>{{cite news|author=William Claiborne|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/73884383.html?dids=73884383:73884383&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=JUN+25%2C+1989&author=William+Claiborne&pub=The+Washington+Post&desc=Angola+Pact's+Unanswered+Question%3A+Savimbi%3BWill+the+Cease-Fire+Agreement+Force+the+Guerrilla+Leader+to+Go+Into+Exile%3F&pqatl=google|title=Angola Pact's Unanswered Question: Savimbi|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=2007-09-20 | date=June 25, 1989|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071001043938/http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/73884383.html?dids=73884383:73884383&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=JUN+25%2C+1989&author=William+Claiborne&pub=The+Washington+Post&desc=Angola+Pact's+Unanswered+Question%3A+Savimbi%3BWill+the+Cease-Fire+Agreement+Force+the+Guerrilla+Leader+to+Go+Into+Exile%3F&pqatl=google |archivedate = October 1, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref> President [[Kenneth Kaunda]] of [[Zambia]] said a few days after the declaration that Savimbi had agreed to leave Angola and go into exile, a claim Mobutu, Savimbi, and the U.S. government disputed.<ref name=gbad/> Dos Santos agreed with Kaunda's interpretation of the negotiations, saying Savimbi had agreed to temporarily leave the country.<ref name=templeave>{{cite news|author=William Claiborne|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/73895392.html?dids=73895392:73895392&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=AUG+28%2C+1989&author=William+Claiborne&pub=The+Washington+Post&desc=Savimbi+Says+Rebels+Will+Honor+Truce%3BOfficials+Try+to+Save+Angolan+Peace+Pact&pqatl=google|title=Savimbi Says Rebels Will Honor Truce|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=2007-09-20 | date=August 28, 1989|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071001050329/http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/73895392.html?dids=73895392:73895392&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=AUG+28%2C+1989&author=William+Claiborne&pub=The+Washington+Post&desc=Savimbi+Says+Rebels+Will+Honor+Truce%3BOfficials+Try+to+Save+Angolan+Peace+Pact&pqatl=google |archivedate = October 1, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref>

On August 23, dos Santos complained that the U.S. and South African governments continued to fund UNITA, warning such activity endangered the already fragile ceasefire. The next day Savimbi announced UNITA would no longer abide by the ceasefire, citing Kaunda's insistence that Savimbi leave the country and UNITA disband. The government responded to Savimbi's statement by moving troops from Cuito Cuanavale, under government control, to UNITA-occupied Mavinga. The ceasefire broke down with dos Santos and the U.S. government blaming each other for the resumption in armed conflict.<ref name=breakdown>Kalley (1999). Page 46.</ref>

==References==
{{reflist|colwidth=30em}}

Here are some pages you might like to see: * [[Wikipedia:Five pillars|The five pillars of Wikipedia]] * [[Help:Contents|Help pages]] * [[Wikipedia:Tutorial|Tutorial]] * [[Wikipedia:How to edit a page|How to edit a page]] and [[Wikipedia:Article development|How to develop articles]] * [[Wikipedia:Your first article|How to create your first article]] (using the [[Wikipedia:Article wizard2.0|Article Wizard]] if you wish) * [[Wikipedia:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] You are welcome to continue editing articles without [[Special:Userlogin|logging in]], but many editors recommend that you '''[{{fullurl:Special:Userlogin|type=signup}} create an account]'''. Doing so is free, requires no personal information, and provides several benefits such as the ability to create articles. For a full outline and explanation of the benefits that come with creating an account, please see [[Wikipedia:Why create an account?|this page]]. If you edit without a username, your [[IP address]] (70.120.190.247) is used to identify you instead. In any case, I hope you enjoy editing here and being a [[Wikipedia:Wikipedians|Wikipedian]]! Please [[Wikipedia:Signatures|sign your comments]] on talk pages using four tildes (~~~~); this will automatically produce your IP address (or username if you're logged in) and the date. If you need help, check out [[Wikipedia:Questions]], ask me on [[User talk:XLinkBot|my talk page]], or ask your question and then place {{[[:Category:Wikipedians looking for help|helpme]]}} before the question on this page. Again, welcome! --[[User:XLinkBot|XLinkBot]] ([[User talk:XLinkBot|talk]]) 15:12, 24 June 2010 (UTC) == June 2010 == Welcome to Wikipedia. Although everyone is welcome to contribute constructively to the encyclopedia, your addition of one or more external links to the page [[:Brad Delson]] has been reverted.
Your edit [http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?diff=369924466&oldid=366037678 here] was reverted by an automated bot that attempts to remove links which are discouraged per our [[WP:EL|external links guideline]] from Wikipedia. The external link you added or changed is on my list of links to remove and probably shouldn't be included in Wikipedia. I removed the following link(s): http://facebook.com/, http://www.facebook.com/?ref=home#!/pages/Brad-Delson/135122633168495.
If you were trying to insert an [[Wikipedia:External links|external link]] that does comply with our [[Wikipedia:List of policies|policies]] and [[Wikipedia:List of guidelines|guidelines]], then please accept my creator's apologies and feel free to [[WP:UNDO|undo]] the bot's revert. However, if the link does not comply with our policies and guidelines, but your edit included other, constructive, changes to the article, feel free to make those changes again without re-adding the link. Please read Wikipedia's [[WP:EL|external links guideline]] for more information, and consult my [[User:XLinkBot/Reversion reasons|list of frequently-reverted sites]]. For more information about me, see [[User:XLinkBot/FAQ|my FAQ page]]. Thanks! --[[User:XLinkBot|XLinkBot]] ([[User talk:XLinkBot|talk]]) 15:12, 24 June 2010 (UTC)
If this is a shared [[IP address]], and you didn't make the edit, please ignore this notice. [[Image:Information.png|25px]] Welcome to Wikipedia. One or more of the [[Wikipedia:External links|external links]] you added in [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brad_Delson?diff=369924829 this edit] to the page [[:Brad Delson]] do not comply with our [[Wikipedia:External links|guidelines for external links]] and have been removed. Wikipedia is [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#LINK|not a collection of links]]; nor should it be used for [[Wikipedia:Spam|advertising or promotion]]. title: White-blotched skate
content:
{{Taxobox 
| name = White-blotched skate
| image = 
| image_caption =  
| status = 
| trend = 
| status_system = 
| regnum = [[Animal]]ia
| [[Chordate|Chordata]]
| classis = [[Chondrichthyes]]
| subclassis = [[Elasmobranchii]]
| superordo = [[Batoidea]]
| ordo = [[Rajiformes]]
| familia = [[Rajidae]]
| genus = ''[[Bathyraja]]''
| species = '''''B. maculata'''''
| binomial = ''Bathyraja maculata''
| binomial_authority = [[Reizo Ishiyama|Ishiyama]] & [[Hajime Ishihara|Ishihara]], 1977 
}}

The '''white-blotched skate''', ''Bathyraja maculata'', is a species of [[Skate (fish)|skate]] from the western North [[Pacific]].<ref>{{FishBase species | genus = Bathyraja | species = maculata | year = 2007 | month = November}}</ref>  An adult is approximately 1 meter in length, and is found at depths of up to 1 kilometer.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bathyraja maculata (White-Blotched Skate) |author=ZipcodeZoo.com |accessdate=2007-11-13 |url=http://zipcodezoo.com/Animals/B/Bathyraja_maculata.asp |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/20120206110921/http://zipcodezoo.com/Animals/B/Bathyraja_maculata.asp |archivedate=February 6, 2012 }}</ref>   Unlike any other known member of the genus ''[[Bathyraja]]'', the white-blotched skate has white blotches on a grey to brown dorsal surface, while the ventral side is lighter in color with darker blotches.  Dorsal side is rough with spines, while the ventral side is smooth. <ref>{{cite journal| last = Ishiyama| first = Reizo|author2=Hajime Ishihara | title = Five New Species of Skates in the Genus ''Bathyraja from the Western North Pacific, with Reference to Their Interspecific Relationships| journal = Japanese Journal of Ichthyology| volume = 24| issue = 2| pages = 71–90}}</ref>

== Range ==
The white-blotched skate is well established to inhabit waters in the Northern [[Sea of Japan]], [[Sea of Okhotsk]] and [[Aleutian islands]].  It was the most commonly caught skate in a [[NOAA]] bottom-trawl survey of the Aleutian Islands in 2006.<ref>{{cite book | last = Rooper | first = C.N. | title = Data Report: 2006 Aleutian Islands Bottom Trawl Survey| publisher = NOAA Technical Memorandum NMFS-AFSC-179| date = 2008}}</ref>
Initially thought to inhabit only the western margin of the [[Gulf of Alaska]], trawl surveys have now found specimens along the eastern margin as well.<ref>{{cite journal| last = Bizzarro| first = Joseph|author2=Michael T. Vaughn | title = First records of the whiteblotched skate (''Bathyraja maculata'') in the Eastern Gulf of Alaska| journal = Northwestern Naturalist| volume = 89| pages = 193–197| url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.1898/NWN08-14.1| doi = 10.1898/NWN08-14.1| year = 2008| issue = 3}}</ref>

If this was a mistake, don't worry: I restored the removed content. If you would like to experiment, you can use the [[WP:Sandbox|sandbox]]. If you think I made a mistake, or if you have any questions, you can leave me a message on [[User_talk:Pinethicket|my talk page]]. title: Bosniaks in Turkey
content:
{{Infobox ethnic group||group=Bosniaks in Turkey
Türkiye'deki Boşnaklar |image = {{image array|perrow=4|width=80|height=90 }} |poptime = 101,000 – 2,000,000{{lower|{{cite web|author=Joshua Project |url=http://www.joshuaproject.net/people-profile.php?peo3=10953&rSušićog3=TU |title=Bosniak of Turkey Ethnic People Profile |publisher=Joshuaproject.net |date=2010-04-13 |accessdate=2012-01-05}}{{cite web|author=[[Milliyet]] |url=http://www.milliyet.com.tr/default.aspx?aType=SonDakika&Kategori=yasam&ArticleID=873452&Date=07.06.2008&ver=16 |title=Türkiye'deki Kürtlerin sayısı! |publisher=http://www.milliyet.com.tr |date=2008-06-06|accessdate=2013-05-05}}}} |popplace = [[Marmara Region]], [[Aegean Region]] |rels = [[Sunni Islam]] |langs = [[Bosniak language|Bosnian]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]] |related = }} '''[[Bosniaks]] in Turkey''' refers to citizens of Turkey who are, or descend from, ethnic Bosniak people, originating in [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]], [[Sandžak]] and other former [[Yugoslavia|Yugoslav]] republics. == Numbers == In the 1965 Census, 17,627 Turkish citizens spoke [[Bosnian language|Bosnian]] as a first language, which is only 0.05% of the population. These people were mostly living in [[Kocaeli Province|Kocaeli]] (1.2%), [[Sakarya Province|Sakarya]] (0.7%), [[Kırklareli Province|Kırklareli]] (0.4%) and [[Izmir Province|Izmir]] (0.2%). Another 34,892 spoke Bosnian as a second language. ==Famous Bosniaks of Turkey== *[[Bülent Ecevit]], politician, served as the Prime Minister of Turkey four times *[[Cem Adrian]], singer-songwriter *[[Ayşe Kulin]], novelist and columnist *[[Ekrem Akurgal]], archaeologist *[[Emir Preldžić]], basketball player *[[Hüseyin Beşok]], basketball player *[[Kıvanç Tatlıtuğ]], actor and model *[[Metin Boşnak]], scholar *[[Ömer Çatkıç]], footballer *[[Cem Uzan]], businessman *[[Hedo Türkoğlu]], basketball player *[[Meliha İsmailoğlu]], volleyball player *[[Tuncel Kurtiz]], actor *[[Semih Erden]], basketball player *[[Suat Atalık]], chess grandmaster *[[Sabiha Gökçen]], aviator, first Turkish female combat pilot *[[Mirsad Türkcan]], former basketball player *[[Emina Jahović Sandal]], singer and sister of [[Mirsad Türkcan]] *[[Cedi Osman]], basketball player *[[Zijad Švrakić]], former footballer *[[Saffet Sancaklı]], former footballer *[[Asım Pars]], former basketball player *[[Sead Halilagić]], former footballer *[[Almir Gegić]], former footballer *[[Nedim Dal]], former basketball player *[[Elvir Bolić]], former footballer *[[Elvir Baljić]], former footballer *[[Ediz Bahtiyaroğlu]], late footballer ==See also== *[[Turks in Bosnia and Herzegovina]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Demographics of Turkey}} [[Category:Turkish people of Bosniak descent]] [[Category:Demographics of Turkey]] [[Category:Bosniak diaspora]] [[Category:European diaspora in Turkey]]

title: User:Ssanchit82/Aid gurgaon
content:
AID-Gurgaon[http://gurgaon.aidindia.org/] is an independent chapter of [[Association for India's Development]][http://www.aidindia.org/main/] (AID), a voluntary non-profit [[Non-governmental organization]]. It is operational in [[Gurgaon]], a district in state of Haryana, adjacent to [[New Delhi]], the capital of [[India]]. Most of the activities of the AID-Gurgaon Chapter is in the field of education, although it has a close association with [[AID Delhi]][http://delhi.aidindia.org/bethechange/] which is a much bigger chapter in terms of volunteers and scope of projects.


== History ==
The seeds of AID-Gurgaon were sown in early 2007. AID-Gurgaon started as a group of working professionals who came together to make a difference to the glaring rich-poor divide that engulfs this modern fast-developing city. Inspired by the model of Mobile Creches[http://www.mobilecreches.org/about.htm], which is an organization providing day-care centers for children of construction workers at construction sites across the National Capital Region of India(and few other cities), the volunteers started the first project of AID-Gurgaon on 26 January, 2007 and named it '''''Unnati''''' (meaning progress).

== Ideology ==
AID-Gurgaon being a chapter of AID-India, follows the same ideology of '''''Sangharsh, Seva and Nirman''''', meaning Struggle, Service and Development. Sangharsh is reflected in the efforts of the volunteers to run day to day activities of the organization. Service and Development are embodied in the educational projects and an awareness campaign being run by the organization.

== Structure and Volunteers==
AID-Gurgaon being a completely volunteer driven organization is not very rigid in its structure. However, there are a few important positions/groups that are important for its smooth running:

1. '''Chapter coordinator''' - Responsible for the overall administration and smooth running of all the projects, resolving any roadblocks and discrepancies at any stage of a project and assigning responsibilities for major tasks to the fellow volunteers.

2. '''Project coordinator''' - Individual projects are the responsibilities of atleast one person. However, due to fewer projects, there are often more than one Project coordinator for a project.

3. '''Website coordinator''' - Responsible for the maintenance and upto date information of all important events on AID-Gurgaon website[http://gurgaon.aidindia.org/].

4. '''Treasurer''' - Responsible for maintaining the constant flow of funds to and from AID-Gurgaon.

== Projects ==
AID-Gurgaon has the following projects running actively:

1. '''Unnati''' - The first project of AID-Gurgaon, started in January 2007, it is a school being run at Jharsa Village of Gurgaon. The school targets children of construction laborers and rag-pickers and provides '''''non-formal''''' education to the students. The school is fully funded by AID-Gurgaon and runs six days a week with a regular experienced teacher.

2. '''Disha''' - Disha is a recently opened (January 2009) school, also located in Jharsa Village of Gurgaon. It is run on the similar lines of Unnati.

3. '''RSEP''' - Stands for Regular School Education Program. This program is intended to promote the students who have been regular to the non-formal education system provided by Unnati and Disha to regular private and semi-private schools.

4. '''Srijan''' - An awareness campaign with a goal to make Gurgaon a Beggar-free town.

For more information on the above projects, see the official AID-Gurgaon webiste[http://gurgaon.aidindia.org/]

== Activities and Events ==
Regular activities of AID-Gurgaon involve:

1. Regular school visit to Unnati and Disha by volunteers (frequency: every weekend)

2. Regular ''basti'' (slum) visit to meet the children and their parents in order to keep both of them motivated for their education.

3. Campaigning activities - online and door to door for Srijan project.

Some other important events include:

1. Republic Day and Unnati/Disha Birthday celebrations event

2. Independence Day event

== Funding ==
Gurgaon being a hub of major IT and other multi-national companies, both volunteers and major part of funding of AID-Gurgaon comes from corporates. In terms of infrastructure and expertise, AID-Gurgaon also gets help from Literacy India, another NGO operating in Gurgaon. Additionally, AID-Gurgaon also gets part of its funding from Atlanta chapter of AID-USA.

title: User talk:Alexcell~enwiki
content:
== Your account will be renamed ==
Hello, The developer team at Wikimedia is making some changes to how accounts work, as part of our on-going efforts to provide new and better tools for our users like cross-wiki notifications. These changes will mean you have the same account name everywhere. This will let us give you new features that will help you edit and discuss better, and allow more flexible user permissions for tools. One of the side-effects of this is that user accounts will now have to be unique across all 900 Wikimedia wikis. See [[m:Special:MyLanguage/Single User Login finalisation announcement|the announcement]] for more information. Unfortunately, your account clashes with another account also called Alexcell. To make sure that both of you can use all Wikimedia projects in future, we have reserved the name Alexcell~enwiki that only you will have. If you like it, you don't have to do anything. If you do not like it, you can [[Special:GlobalRenameRequest|pick out a different name]]. If you think you might own all of the accounts with this name and this message is in error, please visit [[Special:MergeAccount]] to check and attach all of your accounts to prevent them from being renamed. Your account will still work as before, and you will be credited for all your edits made so far, but you will have to use the new account name when you log in. Sorry for the inconvenience. Yours,
[[m:User:Keegan (WMF)|Keegan Peterzell]]
Community Liaison, Wikimedia Foundation
21:48, 19 March 2015 (UTC) == Renamed ==

title: User talk:903kshaw
content:
[[Image:Nuvola apps important.svg|48px|left]]The article [[:Joseph Paul Shaw]] has been speedily deleted from Wikipedia. This was done because the article seemed to be about a real person, organization (band, club, company, ''etc.''), or web content, but it did not indicate how or why the subject is notable, that is, why an article about that subject should be included in Wikipedia. Under the [[WP:CSD#Articles|criteria for speedy deletion]], articles that do not indicate the notability of the subject may be deleted at any time. If you can indicate why the subject is really notable, you are free to re-create the article, making sure to [[Wikipedia:Citing sources|cite]] any [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable sources]].

Please [[Wikipedia:Notability|see the guidelines for what is generally accepted as notable]], and for specific types of articles, you may want to check out our criteria [[Wikipedia:Notability (people)|for biographies]], [[WP:WEB|for web sites]], [[WP:MUSIC|for musicians]], or [[WP:CORP|for companies]]. Feel free to leave a note on my talk page if you have any questions about this.<!-- Template:Nn-warn-deletion -->  [[User:NawlinWiki|NawlinWiki]] ([[User talk:NawlinWiki|talk]]) 03:36, 25 April 2008 (UTC)

title: Talk:Provisional Irish Republican Army/Archive 6
content:
{{talkarchivenav}} ==New discussion== "It is estimated that between 1969 and 1997, the IRA were responsible for the death or injury of over 20,000 men, woman and children. Over 14,000 of these being civilians." - text added. "It has also been estimated that the IRA injured 6,000 British Army, UDR and RUC and up to 14,000 civilians, during the Troubles." - original text. [[User:Ttiotsw|Ttiotsw]] ([[User talk:Ttiotsw|talk]]) 09:30, 8 August 2009 (UTC) ==Getting down to business== A few friendly words, a gesture of good faith, and serious stuff.
File:Royal Avenue Belfast.jpg|Before restoration File:Royal Avenue Belfast2.jpg|After restoration
Been asked to weigh in as somebody with experience in DR and a totally clean slate on Irish nationalism disputes. So started off by spending several hours restoring a historic street scene of Belfast, chewing on this discussion at this page while getting it ready for featured picture candidacy. Found a possible copyright violation on the article during review; tagged it as a possibly unfree file. Down to business. The wrong version usually gets protected during an edit war; see [[m:The Wrong Version|The Wrong Version]]. Here's the disputed text: :''It is estimated that between 1969 and 1997, the IRA was responsible for the death or injury of over 20,000 people: over 14,000 of these being civilians.'' Suggesting the editors here seek formal mediation to resolve the matter. A few points to consider: *Should the casualties section be summarized in the lead? If so, what would a brief and neutral casualties statement include? *Should this material (or something along these lines) move down into the body of the article and be covered in more depth? Possibly with a greater range of sources? *In terms of casualties for this conflict, how widely to reputable sources vary? As a reminder, this article is under general sanctions. Although the issue is a content dispute, recent conduct at this page looks problematic. Please refrain from name calling, vulgar terms, and Godwin's Law violations. Best wishes working this out. [[User:Durova|Durova]]''[[User talk:Durova|299]]'' 20:11, 12 August 2009 (UTC) == An attempt at rewriting the lead entirely == ''((Given that the discussion of the single sentence doesn't seem to be moving towards consensus, I thought I'd try a different tactic and propose a re-writing of the whole opening that shortens it. All of the information that was in the lead is still available int he body of the article itself. We don't need to cover everything before the section heads. For the injuries/deaths thing I just covered deaths and not injuries as a kind of compromise.))'' ''((We'd need to put all the formatting back in))'' The Provisional Irish Republican Army (IRA) is an Irish republican paramilitary organisation that considers itself a direct continuation of the Irish Republican Army (the army of the Irish Republic — 1919–1921) that fought in the Irish War of Independence. It is one of several organisations calling themselves the IRA (see List of IRAs). The Provisionals' constitution establishes them as Óglaigh na hÉireann ("The Irish Volunteers") in the Irish language. The Provisional Irish Republican Army is sometimes referred to as the PIRA, the Provos, or by some of its supporters as the Army or the 'RA. The IRA's stated objective is to end "British rule in Ireland," and according to its constitution, it wants "to establish an Irish Socialist Republic, based on the Proclamation of 1916." Until the 1998 Belfast Agreement, it sought to end Northern Ireland's status within the United Kingdom and bring about a united Ireland by force of arms and political persuasion. Between, 1969 and 1998, the IRA conducted an armed campaign against British and loyalist forces, killing approximately 1,800 people, including approximately 620 civilians. An internal British Army document released in 2007 describes the IRA as "professional, dedicated, highly skilled and resilient." On 28 July 2005, the IRA Army Council announced an end to its armed campaign, stating that it would work to achieve its aims using "purely political and democratic programmes through exclusively peaceful means". The organisation is classified as a proscribed terrorist group in the United Kingdom and as an illegal organisation in the Republic of Ireland. There has been no movement whatsoever. I believe the disagreement stems from the notion that the lead should include "vital" information. As the two sides cannot agree on what is vital, so too is agreement on content impossible. I propose the following solution: Instead of the lead containing "vital" information, make it contain only the following: Who, What, Where, When, Why, and How. Thus the lead would read as a mildly expanded version of: "The PIRA was a [WHAT] that operated in [PLACE] from [DATE] to [DATE]. It sought to achieve [GOAL] through the use of [MEANS]." While the lead will not be this compact, I believe that any information not covered by these criteria will inevitably lead to intractable conflict, and thus should not be included. That means no casualty estimates, no "professional, disciplined, yadda yadda". Remember, the focus of the article is the organization, not the campaign. There is plenty of room within the article itself to discuss any and all contentious issues raised in this discussion. Once again, the lead of the article should not be a place where either side attempts to espouse its ideology. Any properly sourced facts and figures should be included in the appropriate sections of the body. [[User:Tfz|''Tfz'']] [[User talk:Tfz| ]] 22:41, 19 August 2009 (UTC) ====Comments by Sam Blacketer==== Opinions from someone not involved in the dispute. I think the sentence as proposed cannot stand, for several reasons. Firstly, although this is somewhat banal, the source given as an external hyperlink to another Wikipedia article is manifestly inappropriate; if the source is really O'Brien's "The Long War" at pages 135-6, then that should be the source given. Secondly, the lumping together of both those killed and injured as "casualties" is inappropriate. That is what is done in military articles because it is a measure of the reduction of the strength of an army - soldiers who are killed and injured are alike unable to continue to fight. However in this case the point being made is that those killed and injured were not in opposing armies, but mostly civilians. In civilian life the difference between being killed and injured is considered very great and they should not be put together if it is at all possible to make a distinction - which it undoubtedly is here. Thirdly, the sentence raises but does not answer the question of how exactly 'civilian' is defined. Members of the RUC were civilians in the sense of being in an institution of the civil power. Members of loyalist paramilitary groups were civilians, and in many cases there must be uncertainty about who exactly was in a paramilitary group and who was not. Without deeper explanation the sentence as proposed is not helpful. I can see some need for a reference in the lede to the numbers killed by the PIRA, but not in this form. If it were generally desired, a better statistic might be to adapt the table in 'Lost Lives'. I think my edition is not quite the latest but table 20 on page 1504 of the 2001 edition identifies 1,778 people killed by the IRA, of which 642 were civilians under its definition. Some points and questions. * [[WP:ADMINS|admins]] have no special status for mediating disputes. Experienced, previously uninvolved editors are needed for that, many of whom are not admins. Admins are authorised to have access to special tools, not to settle debates. * Tempers have got heated here, but can everyone make a super-human effort to put that aside, wipe the slate clean, and try and focus on the content issues? Otherwise this isn't going to work. Suggestion: try and keep the moral high ground - let others drag the conversation into the mud if they must (and try not to follow them). [[WP:AGF]], [[WP:CIVIL]] and [[WP:NPA]] aren't there for fun, they're essential for debate on difficult topics to work. And please please try not drag up "he said"-"she said"s - try and let bygones be bygones. OK, on to the substance. * The current (protected) version of the article contains the following sentence which I gather is the nub of the dispute: "It is estimated that between 1969 and 1997, the IRA was responsible for the death or injury of over 20,000 people: over 14,000 of these being civilians. [11]" Footnote 11 links to a footnote in an another Wikipedia article ([[Provisional IRA campaign 1969–1997]]), which as Sam Blacketer noted above, is just not good enough. I can't even figure out what the ref is supposed to be, and it wouldn't be good enough even if it was clear. Refs must be contained within the article, not on other Wikipedia pages. * As noted also by Sam Blacketer, mixing death and injury is not a good idea. It is neither helpful for the reader nor [[WP:NPOV]]-compatible. * I suggest that we need 4 numbers from each source, total death and injury and subtotal civilian death and injury. * Drawing on what it says in [[Provisional IRA campaign 1969–1997#Casualties]], we can take the two main sources there (A - University of Ulster and B - Lost Lives) and generalise for the lede (can have more detail in the body perhaps, but obviously less than in the campaign article). A says 1,821 deaths up to 2001, with 621 civilian; B says 1,781 deaths to 2004, with 644 civilian. We can summarise that as "From 1969 - 2004, around 1800 deaths of which around 630 were civilians." The exact stats from each source can be given in the footnote to the sentence. * Currently no details on injuries - where does the 20,000 figure come from? We need sources for this - or extracting this detail from sources A and B if they have it. * Addendum: I've omitted the issue of whether the numbers should be in the lede at all; but I see now this is an issue too. So it may be the summary sentence should go in the body. it would probably be less controversial in the lede as part of a paragraph more generally summarising IRA strength and activities, including estimates of its own casualties. Northern Ireland, i.e. other paramilitary groupings such as UDA, UVF, OIRA, INLA, etc. If we can get a good lead here it could perhaps serve as a model for the others. [[User:Mooretwin|Mooretwin]] ([[User talk:Mooretwin|talk]]) 20:23, 23 August 2009 (UTC) ::::::::::::Are you open to the inclusion of other statistics, such as force strength, in the lede, and the inclusion of similar stats (casualties and force strength) in the articles on the groups you mentioned? I'm a bit wary of including them in the RUC, SAS or other British military articles as that would seem to be soapboxing, or at the very least a violation of NPOV. (throwaway85, public computer)-[[Special:Contributions/96.49.196.32|96.49.196.32]] ([[User talk:96.49.196.32|talk]]) 04:56, 24 August 2009 (UTC) :::::::::::::As above, I see no reason why the ledes for any of the paramilitary groupings shouldn't be similarly constructed where possible. As for police and military articles, those are quite different. The Troubles, for example, are a mere blip in the history of the British Army, whereas they were the raison d'etre of PIRA, UDA, etc. [[User:Mooretwin|Mooretwin]] ([[User talk:Mooretwin|talk]]) 19:46, 24 August 2009 (UTC) ::::::::::::::I concur, although perhaps the RUC article [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Ulster_Constabulary] could be edited in order to reflect casualties inflicted, as they served no other real purpose than to counter nationalist groups, were accused of collusion, extreme bias against catholics, etc, with members of some sections (special patrol group) being accused and convicted of outright terrorism. -[[User:Throwaway85|Throwaway85]] ([[User talk:Throwaway85|talk]]) 19:59, 24 August 2009 (UTC) ==Lead overview== The initial problem in the [[WP:LEAD|Lead]] was the introduction of [http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Provisional_Irish_Republican_Army&diff=306469440&oldid=305357398 this sentence here]. This has been resolved. In an attempt to address the issue above [[User:Lot49a| Lot49a]] had proposed re-writing the Lead as [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Provisional_Irish_Republican_Army#An_attempt_at_rewriting_the_lead_entirely a possible solution]. With the removal of the sentence, this proposal could possibly have become moot. However, some still feel that the lead needs some tending to. Therefore, could I suggest we outline what editor’s feel are the main issues with the current lead, and set about addressing them? If we could use [[WP:LEAD]] as a template for illustrating possible concerns it could help. If I could just make one observation, while editors are discussing re-writing the lead, the comments are all focusing on the inclusion of a pacific piece of information. Is it possible that the issue is not the re-write of the lead, but simply that pacific piece of information? Can we agree which issue is to be the focus of the discussion? --[[User:Domer48|Domer48]]''[[User talk:Domer48|'fenian']]'' 21:29, 22 August 2009 (UTC) * There are no details about what this organisation got up to. "bring about a united Ireland by force of arms and political persuasion." "force of arms" is the only hint at violence there and it gives us no further details. It could state their main method of killing, bomb or bullet and as stated above its vital that the death toll is included. How can we hide this information, it clearly makes the introduction biased without it. [[User:BritishWatcher|BritishWatcher]] ([[User talk:BritishWatcher|talk]]) 21:36, 22 August 2009 (UTC) :At the risk of repeating myself, the key point of [[WP:LEAD]] is that the lede needs be a balanced summary of the entire article. Currently the lede doesn't mention, to pick some things from a skim of the article :*1969 split (and its cause) :*1975 ceasefire :*Electoral support :*Support from other countries :*Other activities, eg Policing of communities :*Details in the "Categorisation" section (that one might be too difficult to summarise briefly) :*Belfast Agreement and decommissioning :*Continuity IRA / Real IRA splinter groups :[[User:Rd232|Rd232]] [[user talk:rd232|talk]] 21:54, 22 August 2009 (UTC) ::My main problem with the current proposals is the attempt to emphasise the civilian casualties by giving a total, then just the civilian total. Why are the British Army and RUC totals not being given as well? It may be obvious that non-civilian=combatant, but only mentioning civilians is not neutral. Another issue is Mooretwin's claim that the IRA were formed in 1969. This is a claim he has repeatedly edit warred to include in this article, to have it reverted as a point of view statement that only gives one of several points of view. [[User:O Fenian|O Fenian]] ([[User talk:O Fenian|talk]]) 22:08, 22 August 2009 (UTC) ::::Strange comment. I have never claimed that the IRA "were" formed in 1969. It is the PIRA that was formed then. [[User:Mooretwin|Mooretwin]] ([[User talk:Mooretwin|talk]]) 19:47, 23 August 2009 (UTC) :::It's a question of brevity with the stats. And that only a third of casualties were civilians seems worth mentioning - many might assume it to be higher. As to the foundation, the lede should reflect the article, which says "The IRA split into two groups at its Special Army Convention in December 1969." [[User:Rd232|Rd232]] [[user talk:rd232|talk]] 22:41, 22 August 2009 (UTC) ::::I do not consider "for around 1,800 deaths (including around xx British Army, xx Royal Ulster Constabulary and xx civilians)" to be that much longer than the proposed text, but I consider it to be much more neutral and less selective over which deaths are included. [[User:O Fenian|O Fenian]] ([[User talk:O Fenian|talk]]) 22:54, 22 August 2009 (UTC) :::::How do the sources concerned define civilian? Is it simply non-military/police, or is it uninvolved lay persons? Does it make any distinction between uninvolved civilians and members of the UDF/UDA?-[[User:Throwaway85|Throwaway85]] ([[User talk:Throwaway85|talk]]) 18:02, 23 August 2009 (UTC) ::::::I think a total death-toll should be given, without categorising the victims. The definition of civilian is problematic. [[User:Mooretwin|Mooretwin]] ([[User talk:Mooretwin|talk]]) 19:47, 23 August 2009 (UTC) :::::::That ignores the fact that the PIRA primarilly chose military and police targets. Most armed conflicts cause more civilian than military deaths. The \pira was an exception, and I believe that warrants notice.(throwaway85)-[[Special:Contributions/96.49.196.32|96.49.196.32]] ([[User talk:96.49.196.32|talk]]) 05:00, 24 August 2009 (UTC) ::::::::That can be addressed in the article itself. [[User:Mooretwin|Mooretwin]] ([[User talk:Mooretwin|talk]]) 19:47, 24 August 2009 (UTC) ::I agree with Rd232's assessment about the lead and I'm struggling to work out how to get all of that in. But I think it needs to. In particular, I'm not sure how to word the 1969 split in an NPOV way, given that in one interpretation the PIRA was formed in 1969 and in another, they were the legitimate succession. Also I know very little about that part of Ireland's history. I'm going to try to get some of the other points into the draft that's in progress [[User:Rd232/PIRAlededraft | here]]. ::I think that the splinter group and perhaps split can be folded into simply acknowledging that there have been a lot of groups calling themselves the IRA? [[User:Lot49a|Lot]] [[Special:Contributions/Lot49a|'''49a''']][[User talk:Lot49a|talk]] 00:45, 23 August 2009 (UTC) :::It is Provisional-republican POV to say that the PIRA was a "legitimate succession" to the IRA. The current lead already attributes this by saying the PIRA "considers itself to be" the successor of the IRA. I think that is the best way to deal with it. [[User:Mooretwin|Mooretwin]] ([[User talk:Mooretwin|talk]]) 19:47, 23 August 2009 (UTC) ::::Go by whenever they first started calling themselves the PIRA as opposed to the OIRA or whatever. I agree with "considers itself"-[[User:Throwaway85|Throwaway85]] ([[User talk:Throwaway85|talk]]) 21:05, 23 August 2009 (UTC) For anybody happening by: there is a redraft of the lede in progress here: [[User:Rd232/PIRAlededraft]]. [[User:Rd232|Rd232]] [[user talk:rd232|talk]] 18:27, 25 August 2009 (UTC)

{{spanish name 2|first=Serra|second=Figueras}}
'''Albert Serra Figueras''' (born 6 October 1978) is a Spanish retired [[Association football|footballer]] who played as a [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|central defender]], and the current [[Coach (sport)|manager]] of CE Besalú (youth).

==Football career==
Born in [[Banyoles]], [[Province of Girona|Girona]], [[Catalonia]], Serra started his professional career at local [[UE Figueres]] in 2000, quickly becoming a regular for the [[Segunda División B|third division]] team. After five seasons, he moved to neighbours [[Girona FC]] in the [[Tercera División|fourth level]].

Girona promoted in [[2006–07 Tercera División|2007]], and climbed yet another division in [[2007–08 Segunda División B|the next year]], with Serra playing 33 matches. He maintained first-choice status in [[2008–09 Segunda División|the following campaign]], in [[Segunda División|level two]], but the club decided not to renew the player's deal,<ref>[http://www.elmundodeportivo.es/web/gen/20090627/noticia_53733486058.html Gusó no quiere renovar a Serra (Gusó does not want to renew Serra)]; [[El Mundo Deportivo (newspaper)|El Mundo Deportivo]], 27 June 2009 {{es icon}}</ref> and he eventually moved to another side in the category, [[Levante UD]].<ref>[http://es.levanteud.com/noticias/levante9114.html Albert Serra, nueva incorporación del Levante UD (Albert Serra, new Levante UD addition)]; Levante's official website, 28 August 2009 {{es icon}}</ref>

After [[2009–10 Segunda División|one single season]], where he featured in less than half of the matches as the [[Valencian Community]] club returned to [[La Liga]], 32-year-old Serra rejoined Girona.<ref>[http://www.marca.com/2010/07/23/futbol/equipos/girona/1279905625.html Serra y Luso, presentados como nuevos jugadores del Girona (Serra and Luso, presented as new Girona players)]; [[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]], 23 July 2010 {{es icon}}</ref> In 2011 he signed for [[UE Olot]] also in his native region, where he played out the remainder of his career.<ref>[http://www.futbolcatalunya.com/index.php?option=com_wrapper&view=wrapper&Itemid=62&lang=ca Mercat Segona B Grup 3 2014–2015 (''Segunda B'' Market Group 3 2014–2015)]; Futbol Catalunya, 31 July 2014 {{ca icon}}</ref>

This has been done under [[WP:CSD#A7|section A7 of the criteria for speedy deletion]], because the article appears to be about an organization or company, but it does not indicate how or why the subject is important or significant: that is, why an article about that subject should be included in an encyclopedia. Under the [[WP:CSD#Articles|criteria for speedy deletion]], such articles may be deleted at any time. Please [[Wikipedia:Notability|see the guidelines for what is generally accepted as notable]], as well as our subject-specific [[Wikipedia:Notability (organizations and companies)|notability guideline for organizations and companies]]. You may also wish to consider using a Wizard to help you create articles - see the [[Wikipedia:Article wizard2.0|Article Wizard]]. Please do not remove the speedy deletion tag yourself, but don't hesitate to add information to the page that would render it more in conformance with Wikipedia's policies and guidelines. title: User:ManojBelbase
content:
Belbase बेलबासे is a surname from the Middle Hills of western Nepal. The origin of the name appears to come from the village Belbas in Pyuthan District. It translates as "Place of Rest", literally staying under a Bel tree. People who moved from there to other parts of Nepal became known as Belbase. They have their family deity Dudhe Mosta and they belong to Madhu Kalya Gotra.

The Belbase is mostly found in Arghakhanchi district and main origin is Khiljee VDC later they are shifted to other villages namely Sidhara , Jaluke , Jukena etc. But now Belbase can be found in everywhere because they are migrant to other places.

Others with this surname come from Arghakhanchi District of Lumbini Zone. Belbases have moved to other parts of Nepal as well as other countries. In fact, The Koirala, Ranabhat and some other cast have the same Gotra 'Madhu Kalya' which means the main origin of these people is same.

	This Nepal-related article is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it.

title: Math Ly
content:
{{Cambodian name|Math|Ly}}
'''Math Ly''' (1925–2004) was a [[Cambodia]]n politician. A former [[Khmer Rouge]] cadre, Math Ly later joined the [[Cambodian People's Party]] and was elected to represent [[Kampong Cham Province|Kampong Cham]] in the [[National Assembly of Cambodia]] in 2003.<ref>[http://www.necelect.org.kh/English/ElectionResult/Result_2003/Result_2003.html "Election results"]. Cambodia National Election Committee. Accessed June 18, 2008.</ref>

Math Ly was born in Kampong Cham province to an [[Muslim]] [[Cham people|Cham]] family. His father, Sos Man briefly served as the Minister of Religious Affairs under the [[Khmer Issarak]] movement in 1954 before defecting to [[North Vietnam]] between 1954 to 1970, bringing Math Ly along. The family returned to Cambodia in 1970 where Sos Man served as the President of the Communist-backed "Eastern Zone Islamic Movement" from 1971 to 1974 before it was disbanded. The following September, Sos Man was poisoned by two strangers at his home in a remote part of the country along [[National Highway 7 (Cambodia)|Highway 7]].<ref>Kierman (2008), p. 33</ref> Around this time, Math Ly served as a cadre for the [[Khmer Rouge]] in the Eastern Zone of Cambodia, but soon broke ranks with them and sided with the Vietnamese forces. When the [[People's Republic of Kampuchea]] was formed in 1979, Math Ly briefly served as the Vice Minister of Interior before becoming the Vice Minister for Agriculture from 1979-1985, and was then offered as the President of the Trade Union in 1985. In the late 1980s, he was appointed as the Vice-President of the National Assembly in Democratic Kampuchea and later was given the position as personal advisor to the King His Majesty Samdach Preah Boromoneath Norodom Sihanouk.

==References==
{{reflist}}

==Bibliography==

* Kierman, Ben, ''Genocide and Resistance in Southeast Asia: Documentation, Denial & Justice in Cambodia & East Timor'', Transaction Publishers, 2008, ISBN 1412806690

title: The Ramblin' Man
content:
{{Other uses|Ramblin' Man (disambiguation){{!}}Ramblin' Man}} {{Infobox album | | Name = The Ramblin' Man | | Type = Studio album | | Artist = [[Waylon Jennings]] | | Cover = WaylonJenningsTheRamblinMan.jpg | | Background = lightsteelblue | | Released = September 1974 | | Recorded = February 1974 - July 1974 | | Genre = [[Country music|Country]]
[[Outlaw country]] | | Length = 32:21
41:50 (with bonus tracks)| | Label = [[RCA Victor]] | | Producer = Waylon Jennings | | Last album = ''[[This Time (Waylon Jennings album)|This Time]]''
(1974) | | This album = '''''The Ramblin' Man'''''
(1974) | | Next album = ''[[Dreaming My Dreams (Waylon Jennings album)|Dreaming My Dreams]]''
(1975) | }} {{Album ratings | rev1 = [[Allmusic]] | rev1Score = {{Rating|4.5|5}} [{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r107198|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic review] | noprose = yes }} '''''The Ramblin' Man''''' is an [[album]] by [[Waylon Jennings]], released on [[RCA Victor]] in [[1974 in music|1974]]. ==Recording and composition== With a slightly more commercial sound than some of his recent records, ''The Ramblin' Man'' remained true to Jennings' [[outlaw country]] image and uncompromising musical vision. The album was released at what was still considered to be the height of the outlaw movement in country music, and this was reflected in its chart success, with the LP peaking at #3 on the country charts, Jennings best showing since ''[[Love of the Common People]]'' in 1967. Jennings produced it himself, although [[Ray Pennington]] co-produced "Oklahoma Sunshine" and "[[I'm a Ramblin' Man]]," the latter of which he also wrote. Pennington recorded "I'm a Ramblin' Man" in 1967 for [[Capitol Records]] and took it to #29 on the country charts.{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|date=2008|page=321|isbn=0-89820-177-2}} Jennings' version would be his second #1 on the country chart and also appeared on Australian charts.{{cite book |title= The Billboard Book Of Top 40 Country Hits: 1944-2006, Second edition|last=Whitburn |first=Joel |authorlink=Joel Whitburn |year=2004 |publisher=Record Research |page=174}} "[[Rainy Day Women]]" was released in December 1974 as the second single from the album and reached #2 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs|Hot Country Singles & Tracks]] chart.{{cite book |title= The Billboard Book Of Top 40 Country Hits: 1944-2006, Second edition|last=Whitburn |first=Joel |authorlink=Joel Whitburn |year=2004 |publisher=Record Research |page=174}} Curiously, the [[Bob McDill]] ballad "[[Amanda (Don Williams song)|Amanda]]" was not released as a single at this time; more than 4½ years later, new overdubs were added to the original track and placed on his first greatest hits album. The song was issued as a single and it became one of the biggest country hits of 1979. The album also includes a gutsy cover of the [[Allman Brothers]]' "[[Midnight Rider]]," cementing Jennings' fearless reputation as a leader of the "progressive" country sound. The photo on the album cover was shot at Muhlenbrink's (formerly the Red Dog Saloon). ==Reception== [[AllMusic]]: "If he had created a sketch of outlaw on ''[[Honky Tonk Heroes]]'', he perfected the marketable version of it here, making it a little slicker, a little more commercial, and a whole lot more unstoppable. If the songs aren't the equal of ''Honky Tonk Heroes'' or even ''[[This Time (Waylon Jennings album)|This Time]]'', ''The Ramblin' Man'' has a wilder sound and a greater diversity of songs that make it seem more unruly than its immediate predecessor and more blatantly outlaw...There are moments of reflection, yet even those feed into the outlaw picture." ==Track listing== #"[[I'm a Ramblin' Man]]" ([[Ray Pennington]]) – 2:49 #"[[Rainy Day Woman]]" (Jennings) – 2:31 #"Cloudy Days" (Billy Ray Reynolds) – 2:41 #"[[Midnight Rider]]" ([[Gregg Allman]]) – 3:24 #"Oklahoma Sunshine" (Hal Bynum, Bud Reneau) – 3:29 #"The Hunger" (Lee Fry) – 3:31 #"I Can't Keep My Hands Off of You" ([[Bobby Borchers]], [[Mack Vickery]]) – 3:38 #"Memories of You and I" ([[Lee Clayton]]) – 4:16 #"It'll Be Her" (Reynolds) – 3:03 #"[[Amanda (Don Williams song)|Amanda]]" ([[Bob McDill]]) – 2:56 ===Bonus tracks=== #"Got a Lot Going for Me" (Dave Kirby) – 2:32 #"[[The Last Letter]]" (Rex Griffin) – 4:07 #"The One I Sing My Love Song To" ([[Wayland Holyfield]]) – 2:49 ==Personnel== *Joe Allen - bass *Leon Rhodes - bass *Larrie Londin - drums *Richie Albright - drums *Larry Whitmore - rhythm Guitar *Dave Dirby - electric Guitar *Thomas Jackson - fiddle *Waylon Jennings - guitar, vocals, production *Alfred Newell - guitar *Billy Ray Reynolds - guitar *Kyle Lehning - piano, engineer *Bunky Keels - piano *Carl Gay - guitar *Duke Goff - guitar *Randy Scruggs - guitar *John W. Wilkin - guitar *Roger Crabtree - harmonica *David Roys - engineer (Technician) *Herb Burnette - art direction *Bob Jones - photography *Ray Pennington - producer *Ray Pachucki - engineer *Bobby Thompson - rhythm guitar *Ralph Mooney - steel guitar ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Waylon Jennings}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ramblin Man}} [[Category:Waylon Jennings albums]] [[Category:1974 albums]] [[Category:RCA Records albums]] [[Category:Buddah Records albums]] {{1970s-country-album-stub}}
